channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: How Climate Change Could Foil China’s Smog-Fighting Efforts
item.description: China is spending a lot of money to address its air pollution problem, but some scientists say that may not produce the results the government expects.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: China is trying to reduce the heavy pollution that often strikes cities like Harbin in the northeast.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Relative Silence on Hong Kong Protests, Mainland Media Outlets Note Arrests
item.description: News outlets in mainland China have weighed in on Hong Kong’s pro-democracy march — to report on the arrests that followed it.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The police removed demonstrators on Wednesday morning from a sit-in that followed Hong Kong's pro-democracy march.

item.title: World Briefing: Gunmen in Somalia Kill a Lawmaker
item.description: Gunmen killed Mohamed Mohamud Heyd and his bodyguard in a drive-by shooting in Mogadishu, the capital, according to the police.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Anniversary in Egypt Draws Protests
item.description: Protesters held rallies in several Egyptian cities on Thursday in opposition to the military’s ouster one year ago of Mohamed Morsi, the country’s first fairly elected president.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: U.N. Peacekeepers’ Pay Dispute Is Resolved
item.description: Diplomats have resolved an unusually bitter dispute over how much United Nations peacekeepers should be paid.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing: Syria Aid Needed, Refugee Agency Says
item.description: The United Nations refugee agency said that 70 percent of its $3.74 billion emergency budget for helping Syrian war refugees remained unfunded, and it warned of “dramatic consequences.”
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Kurdish Officials Seek More Autonomy in Any Deal With a New Government
item.description: Leaders in Kurdistan have said they will not participate in a unified government unless Baghdad grants the region expanded self-rule and accepts the occupation of Kirkuk.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Soldiers with the Kurdish pesh merga at an outpost on the edges of the contested city of Kirkuk in northern Iraq. The city sits on substantial oil reserves.

item.title: News Analysis: Obama’s Blueprint for Fighting Terrorism Collides With Reality in Iraq
item.description: The seizing of large parts of Iraq by Sunni militants has laid bare the limitations of a terrorism policy that relies on the cooperation of often balky and overmatched partners.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER, MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Brazil Comes Around as the World Cup Plays On
item.description: The tournament has not produced the disasters some feared, and many Brazilians who were angry about lavish spending on the event cannot help getting caught up in its spirit.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: Brazil supporters in Mogi das Cruzes watched their team play Chile last Saturday.

item.title: Teenagers’ Deaths Raise Fears of Shift From Political Struggle to Blood Feud
item.description: After four killings of young people, a familiar sense of foreboding was joined by a new kind of fear among Israelis and Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli said it had launched 15 airstrikes against sites in Gaza that are associated with Hamas.

item.title: Open Source: Video Shows Abduction of Slain Palestinian Teenager, Family Says
item.description: Video released by the family of Muhammad Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian killed Wednesday, appears to show his abduction from a street in East Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Google Starts Erasing Links for Searches in Europe
item.description: Google began its effort to comply with a European court ruling that said it must help people clean up their online reputations.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT and NOAM COHEN
item.media:description: One of the deleted links was to a BBC blog post in 2007 about E. Stanley O’Neal, the former chief of Merrill Lynch.

item.title: German Parliament Advances a National Minimum Wage
item.description: The lower house overwhelmingly approved a minimum wage of 8.50 euros (about $11.60) an hour, and the upper house is expected to follow next week.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Memo From France: With Detention of Sarkozy, France Laments Presidency’s Faded Grandeur
item.description: The detention of Nicolas Sarkozy is a new low for an office created by Charles de Gaulle as the acme of political power and the embodiment of French glory.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France, in a television interview on Wednesday.

item.title: German Student Under N.S.A. Scrutiny, Reports Say
item.description: State broadcasters believe the 27-year-old man is being investigated by the agency because of his associations with hacking and encryption groups.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Scores of Militants Reported Killed by Iraqi Army, but Group Seizes Syrian Oil Field
item.description: The toughest fighting was in the northern Iraqi city of Tikrit, where residents said an intense bombing campaign by the Iraqi Army was underway in an effort to retake the city center.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Inside Art: Space Pod Alights at the Serpentine Gallery
item.description: A pavilion resembling a space module, designed by the Chilean architect Smiljan Radic, has opened on the lawn of the Serpentine Gallery in London.
item.dc:creator: By CAROL VOGEL
item.media:description: Smiljan Radic’s pavilion for the Serpentine Gallery, made from glass-reinforced plastic.

item.title: Lens Blog: Portraits on the Street, in the Moment
item.description: Jacques Sonck has spent almost 40 years in Belgium making portraits of people — with odd or singular looks — who capture his attention on the street.
item.dc:creator: By RENA SILVERMAN

item.title: European Central Bank Holds Interest Rates Steady
item.description: The bank decided to maintain its monetary policy, which recently underwent major changes, and said it would change its meeting schedule.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:credit: Arne Dedert/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank. He vowed in 2012 to do "whatever it takes" to save the euro.

item.title: Buddhist-Muslim Mayhem Hits Myanmar’s No. 2 City
item.description: The authorities in Mandalay imposed a curfew after a surge in religious violence, incited by reports that a Muslim man had raped a Buddhist woman.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and WAI MOE
item.media:description: Tin Tin Kyaw mourned near the body of her husband, Soe Min, who was killed in rioting overnight in Mandalay, Myanmar.

item.title: Bits Blog: Google Alerts British News Outlets About Deleting Their Links
item.description: The BBC and The Guardian say that they have received notice of articles that will no longer show up in European online searches, including one about the former Merrill Lynch chief.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Among the links removed from Google's search results in Europe was an article from 2007 about the role of Merrill Lynch's chief executive in the bank's demise during the financial crisis.

item.title: U.S. Embassy in Uganda Warns of ‘Specific Threat’ to Airport
item.description: The alarm was one of several in East Africa where governments have sought to counter the Shabab, a militant group based in Somalia.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Security officials patrolled Kampala on Thursday after the United States Embassy in Uganda warned of a threat to Entebbe International Airport.

item.title: Listening Post: Martin Indyk Cites Israeli-Palestinian Distrust
item.description: Martin S. Indyk, who resigned last week as special envoy for Israel-Palestinian negotiations, says skepticism is the reason peacemaking efforts have failed for decades.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Iraqi Militants Release 32 Turkish Truck Drivers
item.description: The drivers, who had been held for nearly a month, were handed over to security forces at the United Nations’ Mahmur camp in the Kurdish region of Iraq, Turkish officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: China and South Korea Affirm Antinuclear Goals
item.description: The presidents of China and South Korea smoothed over differences to release a joint statement expressing opposition to North Korea’s nuclear weapons programs.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China signed a guest book on Thursday in Seoul as his wife, Peng Liyuan, right, and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea watched.
